toolCalls.output:
L1: # Agent Task
L2: 
L3: Task id: tumor-vaccine-ici
L4: Task title: mRNA tumor sensitization for checkpoint blockade
L5: Reference paper: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade
L6: Reference URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-025-09006-8
L7: 
L8: ## Objective
L9: Read the report and produce all required JSON outputs that satisfy their schemas.
L10: 
L11: ## Inputs On Disk
L12: - Report: `input/report.md`
L13: - Schemas: in `schemas/`
L14: 
L15: ## Required Outputs
L16: - `output/study_overview.json` (schema: `schemas/study_overview.schema.json`)
L17: - `output/quantitative_findings.json` (schema: `schemas/quantitative_findings.schema.json`)
L18: - `output/claim_audit.json` (schema: `schemas/claim_audit.schema.json`)
L19: - `output/public_summary.json` (schema: `schemas/public_summary.schema.json`)
L20: 
L21: ## Constraints
L22: - Do not invent source facts; derive calculations only from values in the report.
L23: - Use line refs as `L<number>` where required.
L24: - Where quotes are required, copy exact report snippets.
L25: - For calculation outputs, line_refs must include every report line used for equations, constants, and numeric substitutions.
L26: - Use relative paths only.
L27: - Never use absolute paths.
L28: - Never use `..` in paths.
L29: - Write valid JSON only.
L30: 
L31: ## Completion
L32: Respond with a checklist of written output files.
L33: After the checklist, stop. Do not call more tools.

L1: # Structured Paper Report: Tumor Sensitization by mRNA Vaccination
L2: 
L3: ## Citation
L4: - Title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade
L5: - Journal: Nature
L6: - Year: 2025
L7: - DOI: 10.1038/s41586-025-09006-8
L8: - Source URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-025-09006-8
L9: 
L10: ## One-Paragraph Context
L11: Immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) can produce durable responses in some cancers, but many tumors remain non-responsive due to weak antigen presentation or poor immune priming. The paper investigates whether intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine can create an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 therapy.
L12: 
L13: ## Study Design Snapshot
L14: - Preclinical arm: multiple murine tumor models with intratumoral mRNA vaccine and anti-PD-L1 combinations.
L15: - Translational arm: a retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, compared by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.
L16: - Mechanistic probes: immunopeptidomics, transcriptomics, and perturbation controls (including IFNAR1 blockade and non-mRNA particle controls).
L17: 
L18: ## Cohorts and Scenarios
L19: 1. Mouse efficacy cohort (combination therapy): 78 tumor-bearing mice pooled across repeat experiments.
L20: 2. Mouse control cohort (vaccine only, ICI only, and vehicle): 84 tumor-bearing mice pooled across matched controls.
L21: 3. Human retrospective metastatic cohort: 130 patients total.
L22: 4. Human vaccinated subgroup: 43 patients.
L23: 5. Human unvaccinated subgroup: 87 patients.
L24: 
L25: ## Quantitative Findings
L26: | Metric | Vaccine/Combination Arm | Comparator | Interpretation |
L27: |---|---:|---:|---|
L28: | Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination |
L29: | Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6% | Strong expansion of MHC-I-presented landscape |
L30: | Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment |
L31: | Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0 | Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors |
L32: | PD-L1 expression fold-change in tumor tissue | 2.4x | 1.0x | Checkpoint axis became more targetable |
L33: | Intratumoral CD8+ T-cell density fold-change | 1.8x | 1.0x | Increased immune infiltration with combination therapy |
L34: 
L35: ## Controls and Null/Conditional Results
L36: - Vaccine-only treatment did not produce durable tumor control in non-immunogenic models.
L37: - ICI-only treatment had limited activity in low-immunogenic baseline settings.
L38: - Lipid particle controls lacking mRNA did not reproduce the sensitization effect.
L39: - Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.
L40: 
L41: ## Mechanistic Chain Proposed by Authors
L42: 1. Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.
L43: 2. Interferon-associated antigen processing and presentation pathways increase.
L44: 3. A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.
L45: 4. PD-L1 pathway activity also increases, creating a rationale for combining with checkpoint blockade.
L46: 5. Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.
L47: 
L48: ## Caveats and Threats to Validity
L49: - The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.
L50: - Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
L51: - Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
L52: - Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
L53: - Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.
L54: 
L55: ## Practical Takeaway
L56: The study supports a biologically coherent hypothesis that intratumoral mRNA vaccination can prime tumors for stronger ICI responses, but prospective randomized studies are required before clinical protocol changes are justified.

  "status": "completed",
  "arguments": "{\"file_path\":\"output/study_overview.json\",\"content\":\"{\\n  \\\"paper\\\": {\\n    \\\"title\\\": \\\"SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade\\\",\\n    \\\"doi\\\": \\\"10.1038/s41586-025-09006-8\\\",\\n    \\\"publication_year\\\": 2025,\\n    \\\"domain\\\": \\\"oncology-immunology\\\",\\n    \\\"study_type\\\": \\\"preclinical+retrospective\\\"\\n  },\\n  \\\"core_question\\\": \\\"Whether intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine can create an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 therapy.\\\",\\n  \\\"datasets_or_cohorts\\\": [\\n    {\\n      \\\"id\\\": \\\"mouse-efficacy\\\",\\n      \\\"label\\\": \\\"Mouse efficacy cohort (combination therapy)\\\",\\n      \\\"sample_size_or_observations\\\": \\\"78 tumor-bearing mice\\\",\\n      \\\"description\\\": \\\"Preclinical pooled mouse experiments testing intratumoral mRNA vaccine combined with anti-PD-L1 therapy for tumor control.\\\"\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"id\\\": \\\"mouse-controls\\\",\\n      \\\"label\\\": \\\"Mouse control cohort (single agents and vehicle)\\\",\\n      \\\"sample_size_or_observations\\\": \\\"84 tumor-bearing mice\\\",\\n      \\\"description\\\": \\\"Matched pooled mouse controls including vaccine only, ICI only, and vehicle, used to assess null and conditional effects.\\\"\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"id\\\": \\\"human-retrospective\\\",\\n      \\\"label\\\": \\\"Human retrospective metastatic cohort on ICI\\\",\\n      \\\"sample_size_or_observations\\\": \\\"130 patients (43 vaccinated; 87 unvaccinated)\\\",\\n      \\\"description\\\": \\\"Retrospective metastatic patient cohort receiving immune checkpoint inhibitor treatment, compared by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.\\\"\\n    }\\n  ],\\n  \\\"major_limitations\\\": [\\n    \\\"Human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.\\\",\\n    \\\"Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.\\\",\\n    \\\"Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.\\\",\\n    \\\"Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.\\\",\\n    \\\"Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.\\\"\\n  ]\\n}\\n\"}",
  "call_id": "call_HDJfZcY0aIi0CJg8LB9f9JDg",
  "name": "write_file",
  "parsed_arguments": null
}\n[tool-call]\n{
  "id": "fc_0d1126cf3c865ebd006990716cf3d08197981d996ba9c3c6dc",

  "status": "completed",
  "arguments": "{\"file_path\":\"output/quantitative_findings.json\",\"content\":\"{\\n  \\\"findings\\\": [\\n    {\\n      \\\"id\\\": \\\"Q01\\\",\\n      \\\"metric\\\": \\\"Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome\\\",\\n      \\\"value\\\": \\\"62.3%\\\",\\n      \\\"comparator_or_baseline\\\": \\\"37.3%\\\",\\n      \\\"interpretation\\\": \\\"Intratumoral mRNA vaccination was associated with broader antigen display in the immunopeptidome.\\\",\\n      \\\"evidence_line_refs\\\": [\\\"L28\\\"]\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"id\\\": \\\"Q02\\\",\\n      \\\"metric\\\": \\\"Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome\\\",\\n      \\\"value\\\": \\\"40.6%\\\",\\n      \\\"comparator_or_baseline\\\": \\\"20.6%\\\",\\n      \\\"interpretation\\\": \\\"The MHC-I-presented peptide landscape expanded substantially after intratumoral mRNA vaccination.\\\",\\n      \\\"evidence_line_refs\\\": [\\\"L29\\\"]\\n    },\\n    {\\n \\\"3.1\\\",\\n      \\\"comparator_or_baseline\\\": \\\"1.0\\\",\\n      \\\"interpretation\\\": \\\"Tumors showed a marked increase in a type I interferon response score following intratumoral mRNA vaccination.\\\",\\n      \\\"evidence_line_refs\\\": [\\\"L31\\\"]\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"id\\\": \\\"Q05\\\",\\n      \\\"metric\\\": \\\"PD-L1 expression fold-change in tumor tissue\\\",\\n targetable after vaccination.\\\",\\n      \\\"evidence_line_refs\\\": [\\\"L32\\\"]\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"id\\\": \\\"Q06\\\",\\n      \\\"metric\\\": \\\"Intratumoral CD8+ T-cell density T-cell infiltration into tumors.\\\",\\n      \\\"evidence_line_refs\\\": [\\\"L33\\\"]\\n    }\\n  ],\\n  \\\"controls_or_null_results\\\": [\\n    {\\n      \\\"statement\\\": \\\"Vaccine-only treatment did not produce durable tumor control in non-immunogenic models.\\\",\\n      \\\"evidence_line_ref\\\": \\\"L36\\\"\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"statement\\\": \\\"Lipid particle controls lacking mRNA did not reproduce the sensitization effect.\\\",\\n      \\\"evidence_line_ref\\\": \\\"L38\\\"\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"statement\\\": \\\"Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.\\\",\\n      \\\"evidence_line_ref\\\": \\\"L39\\\"\\n    }\\n  ]\\n}\\n\"}",
  "call_id": "call_2JG7z81ymfSppCGY3Lzr3cRp",

  "arguments": "{\"file_path\":\"output/claim_audit.json\",\"content\":\"{\\n  \\\"claims\\\": [\\n    {\\n      \\\"claim_id\\\": \\\"C01\\\",\\n      \\\"claim\\\": \\\"Intratumoral mRNA vaccination      \\\"quote\\\": \\\"| Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination |\\\",\\n          \\\"line_ref\\\": supporting a rationale for combining with checkpoint blockade.\\\",\\n      \\\"strength\\\": \\\"moderate\\\",\\n      \\\"evidence\\\": [\\n        {\\n          \\\"quote\\\": \\\"| Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0 | Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors |\\\",\\n          \\\"line_ref\\\": \\\"L31\\\"\\n        },\\n        {\\n          \\\"quote\\\": \\\"| PD-L1 expression fold-change in tumor tissue | 2.4x | 1.0x | Checkpoint axis became more targetable |\\\",\\n          \\\"line_ref\\\": \\\"L32\\\"\\n        },\\n        {\\n   \\\"caveat\\\": \\\"Mechanistic readouts were not uniformly strongest across all tested settings, so the magnitude and generality of these pathways may depend on the tumor model.\\\"\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"claim_id\\\": \\\"C03\\\",\\n      \\\"claim\\\": \\\"Type I interferon signaling was required for the sensitization effect, because blocking IFNAR1 eliminated the observed benefit.\\\",\\n      \\\"strength\\\": \\\"strong\\\",\\n      \\\"evidence\\\": [\\n        {\\n          \\\"quote\\\": \\\"Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.\\\",\\n          \\\"line_ref\\\": \\\"L39\\\"\\n        },\\n        {\\n          \\\"quote\\\": \\\"Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.\\\",\\n          \\\"line_ref\\\": \\\"L42\\\"\\n        }\\n      ],\\n      \\\"caveat\\\": \\\"This requirement was shown within the experimental systems summarized   "arguments": "{\"file_path\":\"output/public_summary.json\",\"content\":\"{\\n  \\\"headline\\\": \\\"Study suggests mRNA vaccination inside tumors may boost response to checkpoint therapy\\\",\\n  \\\"plain_language_summary\\\": \\\"Immune checkpoint inhibitors can work well for some cancers but fail when tumors are not well recognized by the immune system. This study reports that delivering an mRNA vaccine directly into tumors can trigger a strong type I interferon response (3.1 vs 1.0 normalized units) and broaden the peptides displayed to T cells (for example, 62.3% vs 37.3% of tumor proteins represented in the immunopeptidome). In mouse models, these changes are proposed to make tumors more sensitive to anti-PD-L1 therapy. The paper also describes a retrospective analysis of 130 metastatic patients on checkpoint inhibitors in which the vaccinated subgroup showed improved survival (p=0.01), but the authors stress that this human evidence is non-randomized and could be confounded.\\\",\\n  \\\"what_is_new\\\": [\\n    \\\"Links intratumoral mRNA vaccination to broader antigen presentation in tumors, consistent with improved immune visibility.\\\",\\n    \\\"Connects an interferon-rich tumor state with increased PD-L1 activity, supporting a mechanistic rationale for combination therapy.\\\",\\n    \\\"Adds a retrospective human cohort comparison (130 total patients) suggesting better outcomes in vaccinated patients receiving ICI.\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"why_caution_is_needed\\\": [\\n    \\\"The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized, so confounding factors could explain survival differences.\\\",\\n    \\\"Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied, complicating interpretation of the observed association.\\\",\\n    \\\"Mouse model effects and mechanistic readouts may not generalize across all tumor types or clinical settings.\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"glossary\\\": [\\n    {\\n      \\\"term\\\": \\\"Immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICI)\\\",\\n      \\\"definition\\\": \\\"A cancer therapy that removes inhibitory signals on immune cells (such as PD-1/PD-L1), allowing T cells to attack tumors more effectively.\\\"\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"term\\\": \\\"Intratumoral\\\",\\n      \\\"definition\\\": \\\"A way of delivering a treatment directly into a tumor rather than through the bloodstream or a distant injection site.\\\"\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"term\\\": \\\"Type I interferon\\\",\\n      \\\"definition\\\": \\\"A family of immune signaling molecules that can activate antiviral-like inflammation and enhance antigen processing and presentation in tissues.\\\"\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"term\\\": \\\"Antigen presentation (MHC-I)\\\",\\n      \\\"definition\\\": \\\"The process by which cells display peptide fragments on MHC class I molecules so CD8+ T cells can recognize abnormal or tumor-derived proteins.\\\"\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"term\\\": \\\"Retrospective cohort\\\",\\n      \\\"definition\\\": \\\"A study that looks back at existing patient records to compare outcomes between groups, rather than assigning treatments prospectively.\\\"\\n    }\\n  ],\\n  \\\"open_questions\\\": [\\n    \\\"Would a prospective randomized clinical trial confirm that vaccination-related sensitization improves ICI outcomes?\\\",\\n    \\\"Which tumor types and baseline immune states are most likely to benefit from an intratumoral mRNA approach?\\\",\\n    \\\"What dosing, timing, and delivery strategies would maximize interferon
